topic: Amazon Union Loses Election At Staten Island Warehouse
content: Labor Reporter, HuffPost After recently forming the first union at an Amazon warehouse in the U.S., the new Amazon Labor Union suffered a setback Monday by losing an election at a different facility on Staten Island. In a ballot count held by the National Labor Relations Board, workers at the Amazon sorting facility known as LDJ5 rejected unionizing by a count of 618-380. The labor board has not yet certified the results to make them official, and the union may challenge them. The Staten Island warehouse known as JFK8, which employs 8,000 people, was the first Amazon facility in the U.S. to unionize, when workers voted 2,654 to 2,131 in favor of forming a union in late March. The smaller LDJ5 facility employs about 1,500 workers. Had they delivered another victory for the Amazon Labor Union, it could have added fuel to one of the most closely watched organizing campaigns in generations. Kelly Nantel, an Amazon spokesperson, said in a statement the company was â€œgladâ€ that workers were able to â€œhave their voices heard.â€ â€œWe look forward to continuing to work directly together as we strive to make every day better for our employees,â€ Nantel said. Seth Goldstein, a lawyer whoâ€™s been advising the Amazon Labor Union, told HuffPost the union was â€œevaluating our optionsâ€ as it relates to challenging the election results based on Amazonâ€™s conduct. It would have until May 9 to do so. Goldstein said the results were not a major setback, and predicted there would be more elections to come. â€œTheyâ€™re going to win and theyâ€™re going to lose,â€ he said of pro-union workers. â€œItâ€™s not going to stop the organizing.â€ Amazon has aggressively fought union efforts at all its warehouses. The company deployed managers and outside anti-union consultants to hold group meetings and one-on-one conversations with workers, urging them to vote against the union. The company spent roughly $4.3 million on such consultants last year. The union has accused Amazon of breaking labor law by retaliating against pro-union workers and making threats. The NLRBâ€™s general counsel has found merit in some of the unionâ€™s allegations. The union may file a challenge to the results at LDJ5, alleging Amazon illegally swayed the vote. Labor board officials found that Amazon had done so during a different union election in Alabama last year, ordering a do-over vote that was conducted there in March. The results in that election are still unclear due to ballots that have been challenged. Amazon has accused the Amazon Labor Union of interfering in the vote at JFK8, asking the labor board to set aside the unionâ€™s victory there. The labor board still needs to investigate Amazonâ€™s claims related to that election. The new Amazon Labor Union was co-founded by Christian Smalls, a former Amazon employee whom the company fired after he led a walkout over safety concerns early in the pandemic. Smalls and his fellow organizers built a strong committee inside the JFK8 warehouse to combat Amazonâ€™s anti-union message and embolden pro-union coworkers. Following the vote count Monday, Smalls took to Twitter and told supporters not to be discouraged with the results at LDJ5. He said it was a harder facility to organize than the warehouse where the union had won: Despite todays outcome Iâ€™m proud of the worker/organizers of LDJ5 they had a tougher challenge after our victory at JFK8.Our leads should be extremely proud to have given their coworkers a right to join a Union @amazonlabor will continue to organize and so should all of you The election win at JFK8 shocked the labor movement because the Amazon Labor Union did not exist until last year and generally doesnâ€™t have the resources of an established union. Along with the organizing success at Starbucks, the unionâ€™s earlier win has helped kindle hopes of a labor resurgence after decades of declining union membership rates. Right now just 1 in 10 workers belongs to a union, compared with double that rate in the early 1980s. Union density is particularly low in the private sector, where just 6.1% of workers are union members. Labor Reporter, HuffPost

topic: McDonald's Left With Millions Of Dollars Of Russian Food It Can't Use. Hereâ€™s Why.
content: Trends Reporter, HuffPost McDonaldâ€™s is in a pickle. The fast-food titan announced last month that it would temporarily close its nearly 850 locations in Russia due the countryâ€™s invasion of Ukraine. McDonaldâ€™s also pulled the plug on its restaurants in Ukraine, which cost the chain $127 million last quarter, according to CNN. Last month, McDonaldâ€™s said in a statement that it would continue to pay full salaries to all Ukrainian and Russian employees. The company also donated $5 million to its Employee Assistance Fund. Maintaining staff costs, alongside payments for leases and supplies, cost the company $27 million. The other whopping $100 million deficit stemmed from food and other unused items that now must be nixed. â€œResults included ... $100 million of costs for inventory in the companyâ€™s supply chain that likely will be disposed of due to restaurants being temporarily closed,â€ the fast-food powerhouse said in a statement. Keeping a spirit of optimism for the companyâ€™s recovery, CFO Kevin Ozan said: â€‹â€‹â€œWe expect this to be temporary and we certainly donâ€™t take this decision lightly, but for us this is about doing what we think is the right thing to do, both for the global business and for our people locally.â€ At this time no further updates have been issued on the companyâ€™s plans for its locations in Ukraine and Russia. â€œAs we move forward, McDonaldâ€™s will continue to assess the situation and determine if any additional measures are required. At this juncture, itâ€™s impossible to predict when we might be able to reopen our restaurants in Russia.â€ Trends Reporter, HuffPost

topic: OSHA Tells Amazon To Improve Severe Weather Safety Following Warehouse Collapse
content: Labor Reporter, HuffPost Workplace safety officials have ordered Amazon to review its severe weather policies and take new precautions after six workers died in an Illinois warehouse collapse. The letter issued by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration on Tuesday outlined some problems with Amazonâ€™s handling of a direct tornado hit in Edwardsville in December. The megaphone that would be used to alert workers to severe weather was locked and inaccessible, and some workers told OSHA investigators they had never been told where to shelter in place in such a situation. But officials said Amazon had met â€œminimal federal safety guidelinesâ€ for severe weather and chose not to fine the tech giant over the deaths. All six workers who died worked for outside contractors who handle Amazon deliveries. A seventh worker was severely injured. â€œAmazon and all employers should go above minimum requirements,â€ Doug Parker, the head of OSHA, said on a call with reporters Tuesday. â€œEmployers need to have a plan that protects all workers and all people on the property whenever disaster strikes.â€ Amazon spokesperson Kelly Nantel said in a statement that the tornado was â€œextreme and very sudden,â€ and that â€œour team did the right thing, moving people to shelter as soon as the warning was issued.â€ â€œOSHAâ€™s investigation did not find any violations or causes for citations, but weâ€™re constantly looking to innovate and improve our safety measures and have already begun conducting additional safety and emergency preparedness drills,â€ Nantel said. According to the â€œhazard alertâ€ letter sent to Amazon, managers started telling workers to head to the restroom for shelter about 10 minutes before the tornado hit. The designated shelter-in-place location was a restroom in the northern part of the building, but 10 workers, including five of those who died, ended up in a bathroom at the facilityâ€™s south end, near a loading dock. â€œAmazon and all employers should go above minimum requirements.â€ Aaron Priddy, an area director for OSHA, said the tornado struck right near this area of the warehouse, taking off the roof and collapsing the western wall. Priddy said investigators couldnâ€™t determine for sure why workers ended up there â€” because they were told to get to a bathroom (in this case, the wrong one), or because it was the most logical place to go near a loading dock without other structured rooms. â€œWe know there was confusion about exactly where to report,â€ said Priddy, who authored the letter to Amazon. â€œIt just really critically highlights that importance of pre-planning.â€ Priddy wrote that Amazonâ€™s emergency response plan was not tailored to weather events likely to hit Edwardsville. Rather than being â€œcustomized with specific instructions,â€ the plan was generalized and included scenarios unlikely to play out in the area, like a hurricane. Amazonâ€™s plan noted evacuation routes for the warehouse but did not identify the shelter-in-place area. But Priddy also said it was not appropriate to issue a citation against Amazon. OSHA doesnâ€™t have a safety standard for severe weather in particular but could fine a company under whatâ€™s known as the â€œgeneral dutyâ€ clause, which broadly states the employers have an obligation to keep workers safe from harm. Amazon responded â€œthe way we would expect any employer to,â€ Priddy said. â€œBut we did identify several opportunities in which Amazon could improve their severe weather response plan.â€ OSHA officials said Amazon needs to make sure everyone, including contractors, takes part in severe weather drills and knows where to shelter in place. They also said Amazon should create written plans with site-specific guidelines for events like tornadoes, and not just fires. This story has been updated with comment from Amazon. Labor Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Jeff Bezos Questions China's Leverage Over Elon Musk After Twitter Sale
content: Breaking News Reporter, HuffPost Jeff Bezos, the executive chairman of Amazon, implied Monday that fellow multibillionaire Elon Muskâ€™s purchase of Twitter could give China leverage over the platform. Bezos shared a tweet saying that China makes up the second-biggest market for Tesla, arguing it raises an â€œinteresting question.â€ Interesting question. Did the Chinese government just gain a bit of leverage over the town square? https://t.co/jTiEnabP6T â€œDid the Chinese government just gain a bit of leverage over the town square?â€ Bezos wrote. China has a record of media censorship and â€œis one of the worldâ€™s most restrictive media environments,â€ according to the Council of Foreign Relations. Case in point: Twitter has been banned in the country since 2009. Musk has previously referred to the social media platform as the â€œas the de facto public town square.â€ Bezos eventually answered his own question with â€œprobably not,â€ saying Muskâ€™s purchase would prove more challenging for Tesla than the social media company. â€œBut weâ€™ll see,â€ he said. â€œMusk is extremely good at navigating this kind of complexity.â€ Amazon is no stranger to navigating complexities in order to take advantage of the Chinese market. According to Reuters, Amazon removed the ratings and comment sections from its Chinese website after a book including speeches by Chinese President Xi Jinping received a negative review. Amazon also had to work together â€œwith an arm of Chinaâ€™s propaganda apparatusâ€ to launch a China Books section on the American website, including a book praising life in Xinjiang, where China is accused of forcibly detaining 1 million of its own citizens, according to the Reuters report. Musk and Bezos have a longstanding feud that includes a rivalry between their two space exploration companies, Muskâ€™s SpaceX and Bezosâ€™ Blue Origin. â€œJeff who?â€ Musk answered, when asked about the rivalry between the two companies in September, according to The New York Times. In April 2021, SpaceX won a $2.9 billion NASA contract to develop a rocket to take astronauts to the moon, beating Bezosâ€™s Blue Origin, according to The Washington Post. Twitterâ€™s board of directors announced Monday it agreed to sell the company to Musk for around $44 billion. Breaking News Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Jack Dorsey Says Elon Musk Is 'The Singular Solution' For Twitter
content: Breaking News Reporter, HuffPost Jack Dorsey, Twitter co-founder and former CEO, said Elon Muskâ€™s $44 billion purchase of the social media company â€œis the right pathâ€ forward. â€œIn principle, I donâ€™t believe anyone should own or run Twitter,â€ Dorsey tweeted Monday night. â€œIt wants to be a public good at a protocol level, not a company. Solving for the problem of it being a company however, Elon is the singular solution I trust. I trust his mission to extend the light of consciousness.â€ Dorsey started a Twitter thread reacting to Muskâ€™s deal to buy Twitter and take it private, sharing the Radiohead song â€œEverything Is In Its Right Place.â€ Dorsey, who now heads digital payments company Block, formerly known as Square, pledged to help protect Twitter. â€œTwitter as a company has always been my sole issue and my biggest regret,â€ he wrote. â€œIt has been owned by Wall Street and the ad model. Taking it back from Wall Street is the correct first step.â€ He also thanked Musk and current Twitter CEO Parag Agrawal for â€œgetting the company out of an impossible situation.â€ Musk and Dorsey appear to be on friendly terms. On April 5, before Musk decided against joining Twitterâ€™s board, Dorsey tweeted he was â€œhappyâ€ to welcome Musk as a director. â€œHe cares deeply about our world and Twitterâ€™s role in it,â€ Dorsey tweeted. â€œParag and Elon both lead with their hearts, and they will be an incredible team.â€ Iâ€™m really happy Elon is joining the Twitter board! He cares deeply about our world and Twitterâ€™s role in it.Parag and Elon both lead with their hearts, and they will be an incredible team. https://t.co/T4rWEJFAes In February 2019, Dorsey told tech columnist Kara Swisher â€” in an interview via tweet â€” that Musk was the most exciting person on Twitter at the time. â€œI like how @elonmusk uses Twitter,â€ Dorsey said. â€œHeâ€™s focused on solving existential problems and sharing his thinking openly. I respect that a lot, and all the ups and downs that come with it.â€ To me personally? I like how @elonmusk uses Twitter. Heâ€™s focused on solving existential problems and sharing his thinking openly. I respect that a lot, and all the ups and downs that come with it #karajack Dorsey stepped down as Twitter CEO in November, saying he wanted the company â€œto break away from its founding and founders.â€ He appointed Agrawal as his successor. â€œMy trust in him as our CEO is bone deep,â€ Dorsey wrote at the time. Agrawal made no mention of Musk in his tweet commenting on the deal, choosing to instead praise Twitter employees. â€œTwitter has a purpose and relevance that impacts the entire world,â€ Agrawal wrote. In an all-hands meeting of Twitter employees that followed the announcement, Agrawal acknowledged a period of uncertainty. â€œBetween now and closing ... we will continue making decisions as weâ€™ve always had, guided by the principles weâ€™ve had,â€ Agrawal said, according to a recording of the call obtained by CNN. â€œThat doesnâ€™t mean things wonâ€™t change, things have been changing.â€ Breaking News Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Elon Musk Buys Twitter For $44 Billion
content: Breaking News Reporter, HuffPost Twitterâ€™s board of directors announced that it agreed to sell the company to Tesla CEO Elon Musk, climaxing the worldâ€™s richest personâ€™s quest to acquire his favorite social media platform and take it private. â€œFree speech is the bedrock of a functioning democracy, and Twitter is the digital town square where matters vital to the future of humanity are debated,â€ Musk said in a press release. He plans to add in new features, change algorithms and get rid of spam bots on the social media platform. Musk and Twitterâ€™s board were close to a deal after a meeting on Sunday, according to The Wall Street Journal. Musk, who already owned about 9% of Twitterâ€™s shares, said he had secured $46.5 billion to finalize the purchase. The reported agreement follows Muskâ€™s April 14 offer to buy Twitter for $54.20 per share, or about $44 billion, to take the company private. â€œMy offer is my best and final offer and if it is not accepted, I would need to reconsider my position as a shareholder,â€ Musk said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. â€œTwitter has extraordinary potential. I will unlock it.â€ Before the deal, Twitterâ€™s shares had been trading well below Muskâ€™s offer price, suggesting investors had little confidence an agreement would be reached. At a TED event in Vancouver later the day Musk made his offer, the billionaire acknowledged uncertainty heâ€™d pull off a deal, but said he was pursuing Twitter because he believes â€œitâ€™s very important for there to be an inclusive arena for free speech.â€ "I think it's very important for that to be an inclusive arena for free speech... Twitter has become kind of a de facto town square."Elon Musk talks his plans for the social media company at a TED event in Vancouver https://t.co/zQHzqLO1vU pic.twitter.com/xkJWYBuy9E Muskâ€™s interest aroused unease within the company. The day after Muskâ€™s offer, Twitterâ€™s board rejected it and said it would adopt a â€œpoison pillâ€ anti-takeover defense. This â€œdoes not prevent the Board from engaging with parties or accepting an acquisition proposal if the Board believes that it is in the best interests of Twitter and its shareholders,â€ the company added in a statement. Musk in the past has stirred trouble for himself on Twitter. In 2018, he tweeted that he had enough money to take Tesla private, but a court later ruled his claim was false and misleading. At the Vancouver TED event, Musk revisited the controversy. â€œI was forced to concede to the SEC unlawfully. Those bastards,â€ Musk said of regulators, according to Reuters. Following Muskâ€™s 2018 tweets, Tesla stockholders asked U.S. District Judge Edward Chen to stop the CEOâ€™s â€œpublic campaign to present a contradictory and false narrative.â€ Am considering taking Tesla private at $420. Funding secured. The SEC charged Musk with securities fraud over those tweets. Musk settled for $40 million, half of it paid by Tesla. As part of the settlement, Musk agreed to step down as Tesla chair for three years and promised heâ€™d allow the company to preview statements about the company. This is a developing story. Please check back for updates. Breaking News Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Elon Musk, Twitter Reportedly In Purchase Talks
content: Trends Reporter, HuffPost Twitterâ€™s board is in talks to sell the company to Tesla CEO Elon Musk and could settle on a deal as soon as Monday, Reuters reported. The two sides met Sunday â€” just 10 days after Musk offered $43 billion ($54.20 a share) for the social media platform, according to Wall Street Journal sources. Musk had said this was his â€œbest and finalâ€ offer. The New York Times reported that the talks between Musk and Twitterâ€™s 11-member board went into the early hours Monday, and that the two sides appeared to be â€œnearing a deal,â€ though it could still fall apart. They were discussing finer details, including scheduling and fees to be paid if a signed agreement fell apart. Twitter on Monday appeared set to accept Muskâ€™s offer of $54.20 a share, Reuters reported, citing sources. The company may announce a deal later in the day, after its board has met, according to the wire service. Twitter had been chilly about the offer, but then Musk revealed Thursday that he had amassed $46.5 billion in financing to buy the company. The offer to take the company private by the often-unpredictable entrepreneur rattled Twitter fans fearful that Muskâ€™s anything-goes mission could destroy what has become a kind of moderately civilized mass town square. And stockholders have been skeptical that Musk would actually get the money and his proposal together. Musk pushed hard for the deal on Friday when he met privately via video calls with several key shareholders to pitch his purchase, according to the Journal. He vowed to solve the â€œfree speechâ€ issues heâ€™s convinced are hurting the platform. Few details of his plan were immediately available, but he has tweeted about reducing advertising and allowing longer tweets. Some shareholders praised Musk after the meetings. â€œHe has an established track record at Tesla,â€ Lauri Brunner, who manages Thrivent Asset Management LLC, told the Journal. â€œHe is the catalyst to deliver strong operating performance at Twitter.â€ Thrivent holds a roughly 0.4% stake in Twitter worth $160 million. Itâ€™s also a Tesla shareholder. Musk has said he was considering taking his bid directly to shareholders with a tender offer. But even with major shareholder support he would need a strategy around the companyâ€™s so-called â€œpoison pill,â€ a maneuver that would effectively block him from building his stake to 15% or more. Twitterâ€™s shares have generally been trading below his offer price since he made the bid on April 14, typically a sign shareholders are skeptical a deal will happen. But they were up 4% on Friday, noted the Journal. Twitter is scheduled to report first-quarter earnings Thursday. Liza Hearon contributed reporting. Trends Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Federal Officials Sue Starbucks To Reinstate Fired Union Activists
content: Labor Reporter, HuffPost Officials with the National Labor Relations Board have gone to federal court in an effort to get three Starbucks workers who are union activists back on the job. A regional director for the board in Arizona filed a petition for a temporary injunction on Friday, saying Starbucks retaliated against three members of a union organizing committee. Two of the workers were fired and the third was put on unpaid leave, according to the filing. The board official, Cornele Overstreet, asked the court to reinstate the workers at Starbucks with their normal work hours and their disciplinary records expunged. Oversreet also asked that a high-ranking Starbucks official be required to read the court order aloud in the presence of a board official, and that a video recording of the reading be made available to Starbucks workers around the country. The board can go to federal court seeking such an injunction when it believes workers have been threatened during an organizing campaign, and that such threats could lead to â€œirreparable harmâ€ if they arenâ€™t stopped. In this case, Overstreet argues that Starbucksâ€™ actions have led to an atmosphere of retaliation, and that workers could â€œirreversibly loseâ€ the boardâ€™s protections if something isnâ€™t done quickly. If granted, such an injunction would mark a significant win for Workers United, the union thatâ€™s been organizing Starbucks stores around the country since last year. The union has accused Starbucks of retaliating against a number of union activists in order to cool the organizing campaign. In this case, labor board officials found merit in the allegations. â€œIn seeking an injunction, the labor board argues that Starbucksâ€™ actions have led to an atmosphere of retaliation.â€ Starbucks has maintained that it was justified in disciplining the Arizona workers. â€œWe wholly disagree with the claims by the [labor board] in this complaint. These partners were terminated because they violated our established policies,â€ a Starbucks spokesperson said in a statement. â€œA partnerâ€™s interest in union representation does not exempt them from the standards weâ€™ve put in place to protect partners, customers, and the communities that we serve.â€ Shortly before Overstreet sought the injunction in federal court, board officials filed a separate complaint against Starbucks at the NLRB on Friday. That complaint was related to a group of Memphis, Tennessee, workers who were terminated, known as the Memphis 7. Starbucks fired those workers in February after a local television station conducted an in-store interview with them about the organizing effort. Starbucks said the workers violated company policy by allowing nonemployees into the store while it was closed, among other alleged infractions. But a regional director for the board in New Orleans, Kathleen McKinney, said Starbucks fired the seven employees because they â€œassisted the Union and engaged in concerted activitiesâ€ that are protected under labor law. She also said managers â€œconfiscated and removed pro-union materials from the community bulletin boardâ€ at the store. McKinney said Starbucks should have to make the fired workers â€œwhole,â€ including by â€œreimbursing them for all consequential harm they incurred as a result of [Starbucksâ€™] unlawful conduct.â€ The charge related to the Memphis workers would be litigated within the NLRB. But itâ€™s still possible board officials will go to federal court seeking an injunction like the one for the workers in Arizona. Starbucks has roughly 9,000 corporate-owned stores in the U.S., all of which were nonunion until Workers United began organizing last year. So far 26 stores have voted to unionize, and many more have petitioned the labor board to hold elections. This story has been updated with comment from Starbucks. Labor Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Late Disclosures Concealed The Extent Of Amazonâ€™s Anti-Union Campaign
content: Labor Reporter, HuffPost While Amazon workers in Alabama and New York were trying to unionize their warehouses last year, the tech giant hired a large cast of anti-union consultants to undermine the organizing campaigns. Known as â€œpersuaders,â€ these consultants led meetings in the warehouses and pulled workers aside for one-on-one conversations, all with the aim of turning workers against the idea of a union. The law requires that persuaders file timely disclosure forms with the Labor Department, so that workers understand who their employer has hired and how much they are paying them to lobby against unionization. But it appears the firm that performed the most work for Amazon last year did not report its arrangement with the company until well past the legal time frame for doing so, HuffPost has found. Other consultants seem to have filed late disclosures as well. The consultantsâ€™ apparent failure to report their dealings with Amazon within a reasonable amount of time left workers in the dark about the details of their employerâ€™s pressure campaign. Some disclosures werenâ€™t submitted to the Labor Department until the ballots were literally about to be counted in both union elections at the end of March, defeating the entire point of the transparency law. â€œItâ€™s useless to people a year after they provided the service,â€ said Connor Spence, an Amazon worker and vice president of membership for the Amazon Labor Union. Spence was researching Labor Department filings as his union campaign was underway at the JFK8 warehouse on Staten Island, New York. He believed it was important to uncover the consultantsâ€™ arrangements with Amazon so workers could make an informed decision about their vote. But he had little faith that the filings in the Labor Departmentâ€™s online database accurately reflected the scope of the companyâ€™s consulting army. Workers at the JFK8 warehouse ultimately voted 2,654 to 2,131 in favor of joining the Amazon Labor Union, a stunning upset that established the first Amazon union in the U.S. The results are still not clear in a separate union election at Amazonâ€™s BHM1 warehouse in Bessemer, Alabama. Workers there have voted 993 to 875 against joining the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, but more than 400 challenged ballots could still change the outcome. Both employers and consultants must disclose details of their relationships to the Labor Department, just as unions must file in-depth annual reports laying out their finances. The employersâ€™ reports are due at the end of the first quarter the year after the consulting work was performed. But the consultants must inform the government about their dealings within 30 days of an agreement being made with the employer. â€œItâ€™s useless to people a year after they provided the service.â€ It can be helpful for union organizers and supporters to be able to show their co-workers how much their employer is spending on anti-union consulting as opposed to, say, giving them modest raises. As HuffPost first reported, Amazonâ€™s disclosure filings show it spent roughly $4.3 million on anti-union consultants last year, with a typical rate of $3,200 a day for each consultant, plus expenses. More than $2.9 million of that money went to the Michigan-based Rayla Group, whose president is listed as Penne Familusi-Jackson. Familusi-Jackson signed an agreement with Amazon on Oct. 12, 2021, which would have made her disclosure filing due in mid-November at the latest. But Familusi-Jacksonâ€™s disclosure form appears to have been submitted on March 31, the day ballots in both elections were being counted. It listed 16 persuaders on the Amazon campaign. In her contract with Amazon, Familusi-Jackson agreed to file disclosures to the Labor Department â€œwithin the prescribed timeframes.â€ When reached by phone and asked about the timing of her disclosures, Familusi-Jackson said she would get back to HuffPost. She didnâ€™t respond to follow-up texts. Another consultant, Katie Lev, signed an agreement on Oct. 28 for her firm, Lev Labor, to help Amazon on Staten Island, according to Amazonâ€™s annual filing. The contract noted seven other individuals who would work for the firm there. Lev did not respond to repeated emails or phone calls from HuffPost asking about her Amazon work. She appears to have filed a disclosure form on April 21, shortly before this story was posted. Consultants only have to report their activities if they speak directly with workers about unionization, as opposed to simply coaching managers on what to say. Lev wrote in her filing that her services for Amazon were â€œpredominantly employee relations work,â€ suggesting it didnâ€™t need to be disclosed. She said she was doing so â€œout of an abundance of caution.â€ In a recent disclosure for her union-related work on behalf of the custom map company Mapbox, Lev claimed she was â€œhired to educate rather than persuadeâ€: â€œAll voters were encouraged to vote the way that was best for them and not to feel pressured.â€ Levâ€™s firm received at least $371,000 for its Amazon work last year. Consultant Edward Echanique reached an agreement with Amazon on Nov. 8 to persuade workers at the Staten Island warehouse, according to filings. Echaniqueâ€™s disclosure for that work is dated Jan. 3, 2022, weeks after the end of the 30-day window. Echanique didnâ€™t respond to voicemail messages or texts asking if he had disclosed his work on time. Amazon said in its filing that it made no payments to Echanique during 2021, so details of any payments made to him this year probably wonâ€™t be public until 2023. A disclosure form for consultant Bradley Mossâ€™ Amazon work appears to have been submitted on March 30, 2022 â€• the very last day of voting at the JFK8 warehouse. Reached by phone, Moss said the form would have been submitted by the companies of David Burke, a union avoidance consultant who Moss worked for. (The union alleges that in the course of his work, Moss referred to the unionâ€™s leaders, Chris Smalls and Derrick Palmer, who are Black, as â€œthugs.â€) According to Amazonâ€™s filings, the company paid Burke through two entities: a firm called Labor Information Services, of which Burke is president, and the Burke Group, of which heâ€™s also president. Burke first disclosed his Amazon work in a filing last March, and workers were well aware of his presence in the campaigns. His groups received at least $691,000 for their Amazon work in 2021. A woman who answered the phone for Labor Information Services acknowledged that some of the disclosure forms it was responsible for had been late, including Mossâ€™. She attributed it to a mix-up. She noted that an annual filing that detailed the firm's work for Amazon had been submitted in early March. The Office of Labor-Management Standards, a branch of the Labor Department, enforces disclosure requirements. A spokesperson for the office said in an email that it could not comment on specific cases or potential violations, but noted that enforcing the disclosure requirements â€œis our No. 1 priority.â€ â€œWe are aware that some employers and consultants have filed deficient reports, and others have not yet filed reports covering reportable agreements and expenditures,â€ the spokesperson said. The vast majority of filings handled by the office involve unions and their finances. But the officeâ€™s director, Jeffrey Freund, has said heâ€™s trying to improve compliance on the management side. He said the evidence suggests many employers and consultants are not disclosing what the law requires. He has even started promoting a tip line. The Labor Department generally does not pursue criminal cases against employers or persuaders for not filing their forms when theyâ€™re due. If officials believe someone has failed to follow the law, they may open an investigation and pressure the parties involved to rectify something thatâ€™s late or incomplete. But under the law, criminal prosecutions can only arise when the violations are â€œwillful,â€ which can be difficult to prove. The lack of serious penalties is one reason reports are filed late or probably never filed at all. Amazon declined to comment on its consultantsâ€™ fillings. The company submitted its own disclosure report on time, listing the payments to its consultants for 2021 in its report last month. But by waiting until the last moment for an employer to do so â€• that is, March 31 â€• Amazon was able to keep its anti-union spending out of the public eye until labor board officials were counting ballots in both union elections. â€œIt appears the firm that performed the most work for Amazon last year did not report its arrangement with the company until well past the legal time frame for doing so.â€ On Staten Island, the Amazon Labor Union had been asking to hold its election at a later date, according to Seth Goldstein, a lawyer whoâ€™s been advising the young union pro bono. Goldstein said Amazon had pushed for an earlier election and ultimately succeeded, with the labor board setting March 30 as the date for voting to end. Spence knew he wouldnâ€™t see the full sum of Amazonâ€™s anti-union spending until after the fact. â€œIt was very convenientâ€ for Amazon, he said. â€œLiterally the next day they had to disclose how much they paid the union-busters.â€ Spence and others have argued for tighter reporting requirements and stiffer penalties for companies and consultants who fail to disclose their dealings. Terri Gerstein, a senior fellow at the Economic Policy Institute think tank, recently argued in The American Prospect that employers like Amazon should have to reveal their persuaders sooner. She noted the murkiness surrounding the Rayla Group: The firmâ€™s address appears to be a post office box at a UPS Store in Troy, Michigan. â€œâ€‹â€‹When well-paid proxies are deployed to convince people not to unionize, those workers have a right to know the specifics,â€ Gerstein wrote. The victory of the Amazon Labor Union at JFK8 will probably force Amazon and other employers to reevaluate their playbook when it comes to anti-union campaigns. But for now, Amazon still seems reliant on persuaders to make their case against unionization in the warehouses. The Amazon Labor Union says several consultants have turned up at a smaller Staten Island facility, known as LDJ5, where a union vote is expected to be held later this month. Spence said the union was successful at JFK8 in part because workers exposed the consultants and their work, relying mostly on the consultantsâ€™ past filings related to other employers. It wasnâ€™t always easy. Spence said some consultants concealed the names on their visitor badges and refused to identify themselves. He said it would be much better if workers could see their employerâ€™s contracts with consultants in real time, as opposed to having to wait months, or even over a year, to see what their agreement was. â€œWe still won,â€ Spence said. â€œBut it would have been very helpful to show all that [information] to employees.â€ This story has been updated with details on Levâ€™s work for Amazon. Labor Reporter, HuffPost

topic: What Netflix's Subscriber Troubles Could Mean For Other Streaming Platforms
content: Breaking News Reporter, HuffPost In the age of the streaming wars, the news that Netflix suffered its first subscriber loss in a decade prompted questions about whatâ€™s next for the company and the other players in the market. HuffPost looked at Netflixâ€™s response and talked to experts in the industry to answer some of those queries. Netflix, which is still the top player in the industry â€” at least for now â€” with almost 222 million subscribers, attributed the drop in subscribers in part to Russiaâ€™s war in Ukraine, as the company suspended its service in Russia and gradually shut down all Russian paid subscriptions. In an effort to cut its losses, the company announced it will roll out a lower-priced, ad-supported version of its service, a move that has long been resisted by CEO Reed Hastings, and will also crack down on password sharing, as the company estimates 100 million households worldwide have been free riders on the service. â€œThose who have followed Netflix know that Iâ€™ve been against the complexity of advertising and a big fan of the simplicity of subscription,â€ Hastings said in a first-quarter earnings interview. â€œBut as much Iâ€™m a fan of that, Iâ€™m a bigger fan of consumer choice. And allowing consumers who would like to have a lower price and are advertising-tolerant get what they want makes a lot of sense.â€ Hastings said the company is hoping to add the plan over the next two years. George Geis, a professor at the UCLA Anderson School of Management, said people in the industry used to say Netflix was a guaranteed winner. However, â€œNetflix has some challenges with respect to figure out how to add additional media to its traditional content streaming,â€ Geis told HuffPost. â€œAnd itâ€™s not going to be easy.â€ He added that Netflix will have to see if the steps it has already announced, along with a push into gaming, will be enough to turn the company around. Another area the streaming service could expand into is live sports. Asked if the company is also looking at sports, Ted Sarandos, co-CEO of Netflix, said leadership is not sure adding that offering would contribute meaningfully to the companyâ€™s profit. â€œIâ€™m not saying we never would do sports, but we would have to see a path to growing a big revenue stream and a big profit stream with it,â€ Sarandos said during the earnings call. The company is instead focused on â€œsports-adjacent programming,â€ like â€œFormula 1: Drive To Surviveâ€ and other sports documentaries. Geis also said Netflix would have to overcome the churn that a lot of markets in the U.S. are seeing and get more disciplined on spending moving forward. â€œSomehow it must get a must-see program on a regular basis, if itâ€™s going to stop that churn, and somehow it must do that in a way that doesnâ€™t allocate $20 billion a year to programming costs,â€ Geis said. Still, Geis warned, Netflix is facing an existential threat. â€œI think Netflix right now is in a battle for its life, particularly its valuable life,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s really a serious battle.â€ Asked if other companies with a streaming offering should be worried by Netflixâ€™s news, Jim Milio, an executive producer who has worked in the film and TV industry for 40 years, said, â€œIt depends on how diversified they are.â€ â€œWhen you look at Netflix, it really just is a streamer,â€ Milio told HuffPost. â€œThey didnâ€™t diversify. They didnâ€™t buy other companies. They donâ€™t really have a lot of things to fall back on, aside from subscription base.â€ That means companies like Disney, Amazon and Apple, which have other businesses besides their streaming platform, could be in a better position. â€œI think the big lesson here is that streaming is not the be-all and end-all,â€ Geis said. â€œStreaming is an intriguing market, but itâ€™s not going to be the one thatâ€™s going to be able to sustain any companies,â€ he continued. As consumers, we have a plethora of options when it comes to streaming platforms. Milio doesnâ€™t think all of them will survive. â€œSome are going to fall, some are going to merge, some are going to be acquired. And some, like Quibi, are going to go out of business,â€ Milio said. Quibi, a streaming service designed to offer short videos on smartphones, shut down six months after launching, even though it had raised $1.75 billion. CNN+, a subscription service that launched at the end of March, confirmed Thursday that it would be shutting down on April 30. CNNâ€™s former parent company, Warner Media, merged with Discovery just weeks after the launch of the service, which reportedly has about 150,000 subscribers. David Zaslaz, CEO of the newly formed Warner Bros. Discovery, has said he wants to have all the companyâ€™s brands under one streaming service and was annoyed that CNN+ launched shortly before the merger, according to Variety. Fox News, which also launched a streaming service called â€œFox Nationâ€ in 2018, has yet to publish how many subscribers it has. Breaking News Reporter, HuffPost

topic: Twitter Users Mock Matt Gaetz's 1st Tweet After His Pardon Request Is Made Public
content:
Senior Reporter, HuffPost Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-Fla.) became a victim of â€œpardon bombingâ€ Thursday on Twitter. It happened after the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol revealed that the lawmaker was one of at least five members of Congress who attempted to get pardons from then-President Donald Trump for their roles in helping Trump attempt to overturn the 2020 presidential election. But Gaetz wanted his pardon to be a lot broader than his role in Trumpâ€™s election fraud, according to Cassidy Hutchinson, a former aide to White House chief of staff Mark Meadows. She told the committee that Gaetz had been pushing for a pardon since early December, according to Business Insider. Former White House senior adviser Eric Herschmann told the committee that the â€œgeneral toneâ€ of the pardon request revolved around the idea that â€œWe may get prosecuted because we were defensive of, you know, the presidentâ€™s positions on these things.â€ However, Herschmann noted that the pardon Gaetz was angling for may have been intended to also protect him from the sex trafficking investigation swirling around him. â€œThe pardon that he was discussing, requesting, was as broad as you could describe, from... the beginning of time up until today, for any and all things,â€ Herschmann told the committee. After the revelation, Gaetz posted on Twitter to accuse the committee of being â€œan unconstitutional political sideshowâ€ that is â€œrapidly losing the interest of the American people and now resorts to siccing federal law enforcement on political opponents.â€ The January 6 Committee is an unconstitutional political sideshow. It is rapidly losing the interest of the American people and now resorts to siccing federal law enforcement on political opponents. Many Twitter users responded with variations on the same joke. I beg your pardon? Pardon me? Beg your pardon?@RepAndyBiggsAZ @Jim_Jordan@RepMTG@RepMoBrooks@RepMattGaetz @RepGosar @replouiegohmert@RepScottPerry Pardon me? Traitor says what? Others pointed out that innocent people rarely request pardons. Wow. Congressmen helping Trump on & before 1/6 & then demanding pardons. Why did you ask for a pardon? Cheers ğŸ» You sought a pardon because you knew you committed a crime, helping Trump try to overturn the election.Sit down. https://t.co/jNzth4P0m2 You asked for a pardon, and now the DOJ will impolitely ask you to head to your cell, Matt. One person had a pertinent question for the congressman. Beg your pardon, Matt, do you take Venmo? pic.twitter.com/WyeVsMR92d Senior Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost?

topic: At Least 5 Members Of Congress Asked Trump For Pardons, According To Jan. 6 Committee
content:
Senior Reporter, HuffPost Senior Politics Reporter, HuffPost WASHINGTON â€• The House select committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol named five additional Republican Congress members who sought pardons from President Donald Trump. The requests stemmed from their involvement in Trumpâ€™s schemes to try to subvert the 2020 presidential election, which Trump insisted he won despite losing by several million votes. The committee previously revealed that Rep. Scott Perry (R-Pa.) sought a presidential pardon, something the congressman denied. During Thursdayâ€™s public hearing on Capitol Hill, witnesses close to the Trump White House said in previously recorded interviews that Republican Reps. Matt Gaetz (Fla.), Mo Brooks (Ala.), Andy Biggs (Ariz.) and Louie Gohmert (Texas) also asked for pardons. â€œThe pardon he was requesting was as broad as you can describe ... for any and all things,â€ former Trump White House lawyer Eric Herschmann said of Gaetz in video testimony that the committee played on Thursday. Cassidy Hutchinson, an aide to former White House chief of staff Mark Meadows, confirmed to the committee that Gaetz and the other GOP members of Congress sought pardons. â€œMr. Gaetz and Mr. Brooks I know both advocated for there to be a blanket pardon,â€ Hutchinson said. In a statement after the hearing, a spokesperson for Brooks said the congressman only wanted a pardon in case Democrats abused the justice system and started â€œprosecuting and jailingâ€ their political opponents. Brooks also released an image of the email he sent to the White House in December, on behalf of himself and Gaetz, recommending that the president give â€œgeneral (all purpose) pardonsâ€ to every Republican who voted to overturn the election after the Jan. 6 riot. In a speech at Trumpâ€™s rally before the attack on the U.S. Capitol, Brooks said, â€œToday is the day American patriots start taking down names and kicking ass.â€ Hutchinson said that she heard Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.) also asked for a pardon but that she didnâ€™t hear it directly. â€œI heard that she asked the White House counselâ€™s office for a pardon,â€ she said. â€œThe only reason I know to ask for a pardon is because you think youâ€™ve committed a crime,â€ Jan. 6 committee member Adam Kinzinger (R-Ill.) said. In a tweet after the hearing, Greene didnâ€™t exactly deny that she had asked for a pardon but said, â€œSaying â€˜I heardâ€™ means you donâ€™t know. Spreading gossip and lies is exactly what the January 6th Witch Hunt Committee is all about.â€ Thursdayâ€™s hearing featured testimony from former Justice Department officials Jeffrey Rosen and Richard Donoghue, as well as Office of Legal Counsel director Steven Engel, who described Trumpâ€™s efforts to throw out the election despite their objections that doing so would be unconstitutional and contrary to the will of the American voters. Donoghue, who was then acting deputy attorney general, testified that when Trump threatened to replace Rosen as the acting attorney general with Jeffrey Clark, an assistant attorney general in the departmentâ€™s Environment and Natural Resources Division, he was told the change would spark mass resignations in the Justice Department. â€œMr. President, I would resign immediately. I would not work one minute for this guy,â€ Donoghue said he told Trump, referring to Clark. During the Jan. 6 committee hearing, Kinzinger described how Perry lobbied the White House to elevate Clark in the Justice Department in order to gain his help in subverting the election. Perry improperly brought Clark to a White House meeting and texted White House chief of staff Mark Meadows, urging him to appoint Clark to a role with â€œthe authority to enforce what needs to be done.â€ Perry denied seeking a pardon earlier this month. â€œThe notion that I ever sought a Presidential pardon for myself or other Members of Congress is an absolute, shameless, and soulless lie,â€ Perry said on Twitter. Kinzinger deliberately juxtaposed testimony about pardon-seekers with the live testimony from Justice Department officials who refused to do Trumpâ€™s bidding. â€œThey knew that every bit of what they did was a lie and it was wrong,â€ Kinzinger said of those who sought pardons. â€œThat is all the more reason to respect those who came here to testify today.â€ Trump last week reiterated his intention to pardon people charged in connection with U.S. Capitol riot if he becomes president again in 2024. â€œAnd if I become president, someday if I decide to do it, I will be looking at them very, very seriously for pardons,â€ Trump said of defendants in the insurrection. Senior Reporter, HuffPost Senior Politics Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost?

topic: Angry Trump Again Demands The Impossible From Jan. 6 Panel After Riveting Hearing
content:
Trends Reporter, HuffPost Former President Donald Trumpâ€™s reaction Thursday to another powerful day of testimony before the House select committee investigating the U.S. Capitol riot was to again demand the impossible: evidence of a rigged presidential election. â€œThe only thing not discussed by the Unselects, in any way, shape, or form, is the irrefutable evidence of massive and totally pervasive ELECTION FRAUD & IRREGULARITIES which took place during the 2020 Presidential Election. They refuse to go there,â€ he posted. It wasnâ€™t discussed because it never happened. A litany of testimony from former Department of Justice officials on Thursday â€” and in earlier sessions â€” refuted Trumpâ€™s â€œirrefutableâ€ claims. Trump appears to be ignoring the information in the hearings the same way he ignored responses from his Justice Department, various state officials and U.S. Attorney General William Barr: The claims of a rigged election were baseless. A number of specific claims have been refuted in detail. Trump insisted on Truth Social that it would be â€œimpossibleâ€ for the Jan. 6 hearing to â€œrefute or challenge that which would be put before them. To the Unselects, I ask, LET US PUT ON THE EVIDENCE STATE BY STATE.â€ Neither he nor his supporters have offered any such evidence. Arizona House Speaker Rusty Bowers (R) testified Tuesday that Trump lawyer Rudy Giuliani asked him to hold up electoral votes because â€œ200,000 illegal immigrantsâ€ and more than 5,000 â€œdead peopleâ€ voted in the state. Bowers told Giuliani he wanted names and was promised he would get them, he said. Despite repeated requests, he was never given a single name, Bowers testified. Last week, Trump noted on Truth Social that the â€œUnselect Committee refuses to debate the Election results, the reason for the massive crowd on January 6th, because they canâ€™t.â€ In a separate post Thursday, Trump asked: â€œWhat about the massive ballot stuffing shown ... by the highly respected and credible Patriots of Truth (2000 Mules).â€ He was referring to a discredited â€œdocumentary,â€ which elicited a derisive laugh from the former attorney general during Barrâ€™s testimony. â€œI suppose thatâ€™s OK by the Unselects? Such lies!â€ Trump added in his post. Trends Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost?

topic: Former U.S. Attorney General Highlights Trump's 'Smoking Gun' In New Jan. 6 Testimony
content:
Senior Reporter, HuffPost Former U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder on Thursday identified what he called the â€œsmoking gunâ€ for criminally charging former President Donald Trump over his conspiracy to overthrow the 2020 presidential election. Appearing Thursday before the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol, Richard Donoghue, the acting deputy attorney general in the last weeks of the Trump administration, testified that Trump directed him to â€œjust say the election was corrupt and leave the rest to me and the Republican congressmenâ€ during a Dec. 27, 2020, conversation. Donoghue had written the directive down in his notes and testified that it was an â€œexact quote from the president.â€ â€œThis is the smoking gun. Coupled with other testimony, [it] demonstrates both Trumpâ€™s substantive involvement and corrupt intent, requisite state of mind,â€ tweeted Holder, who served in the Barack Obama administration. Any prosecution of Trump would need to convince a jury that Trump acted with criminal intent to overturn the results of the election, knowing that he had legitimately lost. Trump - â€œJust say the election was corrupt and leave the rest to me and the Republican congressmenâ€. This is the smoking gun. Coupled with other testimony demonstrates both Trumpâ€™s substantive involvement and corrupt intent, requisite state of mind. Donoghue also wrote down that Trump said the Justice Department had â€œan obligation to tell people that this was an illegal, corrupt election.â€ Asked if the Department of Justice had actually found evidence of corruption in the 2020 presidential election, Donoghue said: â€œThere were isolated instances of fraud. None of them came close to calling into question the outcome of the election in any individual state.â€ Thursdayâ€™s hearing focused on efforts by Trump and his allies to pressure Justice Department officials into supporting his scheme to overturn democracy and remain in power. A number of former Justice Department officials have said the Jan. 6 committeeâ€™s hearings have delivered compelling evidence that Trump committed crimes. Donald Ayer, a former deputy attorney general in the George H.W. Bush administration, told The Guardian last week that â€œthe committee hearings have bolstered the need to seriously consider filing criminal charges against Trump.â€ The current attorney general, Merrick Garland, has not yet indicated if Trump is under investigation or if there will be indictments, though he said he would be following the hearings closely. topic: Bob Woodward: 20% Of Republicans Would Now Like To 'Push Trump Off The Cliff'
content:
Trends Reporter, HuffPost Washington Post Watergate journalist Bob Woodward said Thursday on CNN that â€œdramaticâ€ hearings by the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection are having such a significant impact that â€œat least 20% of Republicansâ€ would now like to figuratively â€œpushâ€ Donald Trump â€œoff the cliff.â€ Whether Republicans are watching the hearings â€œor not, a lot of them know that the earth is shaking,â€ Woodwardâ€™s Watergate partner Carl Bernstein added in a panel interview with Anderson Cooper. â€œWhy is the earth shaking? Because â€œboth the committee and the Justice Departmentâ€ know that â€œbefore, during and after Jan. 6,â€ there was a â€œmassive obstruction and conspiracy from the president down ... to not allow the transition of power,â€ Bernstein said. â€œWhat we do know, factually, is the Justice Department has the evidence of this massive conspiracy and cover-up,â€ he added John Dean, a Richard Nixon White House counsel who flipped on him, said the insurrection proceedings are â€œworking much better than the Watergate hearings,â€ with â€œvery effective ... presentations.â€ Theyâ€™re â€œprobably getting to Trump because they are so effective. He appreciates good media.â€ â€œWe forget how protracted the Watergate hearings were,â€ Dean noted. â€œThey were seven months. I didnâ€™t testify for a few hours; I testified for five days, eight hours a day. They were grinding. Woodward agreed that the House select committeeâ€™s hearings are â€œvery dramatic.â€ â€œI think if you can step back, whatâ€™s going on here right now in the Republican Party ... 50% roughly of the Republicans would walk off the cliff for Donald Trump,â€ said Woodward. â€œNow I think at least 20% want to push him off the cliff.â€ And 30% are fixated on simply winning, Woodward noted. â€œIf thereâ€™s one lesson from writing three books about Trump, spending hours interviewing him, there is the lexicon: Win. You have to win. And they want to win,â€ he added. Voters â€œcan make the calculation: Is this a winning hand with Donald Trump or not? And itâ€™s eroding. Whether significant, we will see.â€ The hearings are uncovering â€œmeaty, dramaticâ€ information, Woodward said. topic: Senate Passes Bipartisan Gun Safety Bill A Month After Uvalde Shooting
content:
Senior Politics Reporter, HuffPost WASHINGTON â€• The Senate approved a bipartisan bill on Thursday aimed at curbing gun violence, taking action a month after the horrific mass shooting at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, amped up pressure on a response in Congress. Fifteen Republicans joined all Democrats in support of the measure. The House is expected to pass the bill on Friday and send it to President Joe Bidenâ€™s desk for his signature. The legislation, titled the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act, includes modest curbs on obtaining firearms as well as funding to bolster mental health care and school security. Itâ€™s the product of bipartisan compromise after weeks of negotiations led by Sens. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) and John Cornyn (R-Texas). The measure enhances background checks for people under 21, incentivizes states to adopt â€œred flagâ€ laws, which help remove guns from the hands of people who have been deemed a danger to themselves or others, and prohibits romantic partners convicted of domestic violence who are not married to their victim from getting firearms. It does not include broader restrictions sought by gun control advocates, however, such as bans on assault weapons, raising the minimum age to purchase semi-automatic rifles to 21, mandating safe storage rules at home, or requiring background checks on internet sales and at gun shows. Nevertheless, itâ€™s the most significant federal gun legislation in decades. Democrats and gun control advocacy groups welcomed it as a sign of progress after years of congressional gridlock on dealing with gun violence. â€œThis will become the most significant piece of anti-gun-violence legislation Congress has passed in three decades,â€ Murphy said ahead of the vote. â€œThis bill also has the chance to prove to the weary American public that democracy is not so broken, that it is able to rise to the moment.â€ Cornyn, who was met with a chorus of boos at his state party convention last Friday, acknowledged that Republicans had to go outside their comfort zone. But he said the â€œpotential we have to save lives is worth any sort of concession we might have had to make during negotiations.â€ â€œI donâ€™t believe in doing nothing in the face of what weâ€™ve seen in Uvalde and other communities. Doing nothing is an abdication of our responsibility,â€ he said. Senior Politics Reporter, HuffPost Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost?
